author: TheBlackCat
message: Any plans to implement sorting and/or filtering by image resolution?

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: Not for now. What would be the use case for this?

replies.author: DanaKil
replies.message:
I see one use case : it allows you to look into a messy image folder for a wallpaper that fits your screen (it could be searched by ratio too)

Cheers :)

replies.author: TheBlackCat
replies.message:
It wouldn't just be wallpapers.

Imagine you have a folder full of images of a certain category (say computers), and you want some image of that category for a particular use, say a presentation or poster. If it is going to look reasonable, you need a higher-resolution image (at least 500 pixels, probably). Currently you would need to look through every single image to figure out which ones have high enough resolution to be usable. Then, most likely, you will need to move those images to another folder in order to look through those to find the one you like the best.

This would allow you to filter it to just those over a certain dimension (or put the higher-resolution images at the beginning or end). This is the most common use-case for me, and what made me notice it was missing.

Some others:
looking for high-resolution photos for a physical photo album
looking for low-resolution images suitable for easy emailing or posting on the web
navigating a folder with a bunch of copies of the same set of pictures at different resolutions
looking for forum avatars or signatures you made at a specific resolution
navigating a really massive and poorly-organized folder, where you know the general size range of the picture you want, but not its file name

author: Teun
message:
Aurélien,

Thanks for the great work on Gwenview and the other KDE stuff.
A question I haven't found an answer on, I like to use keyboard short cuts for zooming and wonder if it is possible to user-define the amount of zoom each key press gives, like 5% or 10%?

Best regards.
Teun

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: No, this is not possible. Actually the zoom steps are not linear, it goes this way: 1/16, 1/8, 1/4, 1/2, 1, 2, 3...16 with the "snap zoom" values (ie value for each you see whole width, or whole height or whole image) inserted in between.

author: ike ahloe
message:
i asked before about hiding the top bar and putting controls like in unity (and plasma-netbook). you told me to check out plasma desktop.

it's just my personal opinion but i think plasma-netbook is a bit unintuitive. theres a lot of stuff everywhere and the visual queues and workflow don't help guide me. i feel/am dumb using it as it's supposed to be simple but i don't know what's going on. :/. It's also more restrictive than p-desktop (understandably so, not criticism).

I wish that the ability to hide the top border when using the application control widget would be extended to plasma-desktop. It would then be nice to have an alternate application control widget that was just the oxygen icons for close, minimize, restore/max... options for button order, app icon, name, etc could be configured in the widget's settings similar to how one sets up the buttons for a window theme.

this would help people attracted to unity's space saving setup enjoy the feature in kde, especially since it's already kind of there in netbook and in widgets.

i guess i'm just not sure why the work was put into allowing that in netbook but not allowing it as an option in desktop. as a desktop user that does 2d and 3d art, screen space is a big deal not just to netbook users, i hate seeing a big wasted bar of space when good alternative methods are over half written.

sorry to blab, just thinking aloud. i like to hear your responses to people. (though not technically.... visually and textually i guess is better.)

i'd be happy to try to code it in this summer once i'm done with school and have some time to learn code, what coding do you suggest learning for plasma and widget type work.
